message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Adaptive Fuzzy Tracking Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With Unknown Control Gain Functions
Paper Abstract: This article investigates the adaptive fuzzy output-feedback backstepping control design problem for uncertain strict-feedback nonlinear systems in the presence of unknown virtual and actual control gain functions and unmeasurable states. A fuzzy state observer is designed via fuzzy-logic systems, thus the unmeasurable states are estimated based on the designed fuzzy state observer. By constructing the logarithm Lyapunov functions and incorporating the property of the fuzzy basis functions and bounded control design technique into the adaptive backstepping recursive design, a novel observer-based adaptive fuzzy output-feedback control method is developed. The proposed fuzzy adaptive output-feedback backstepping control scheme can remove the restrictive assumptions in the previous literature that the virtual control gains and actual control gain functions must be constants. Furthermore, it can make the control system be semiglobally uniformly ultimately boundedness (SGUUB) and keep the observer and tracking errors to remain in a small neighborhood of the origin. The numerical simulation example is presented to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme and theory.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Lyapunov functions and stability:

## Definition and Purpose

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Key Concept

Lyapunov's realization was that stability can be proven without requiring knowledge of the true physical energy, provided a Lyapunov function can be found to satisfy the above constraints. The intuition is similar to analyzing energy in physical systems: if the system loses energy over time and the energy is never restored then eventually the system must grind to a stop and reach some final resting state.

## Stability Types

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance...) remain close enough but asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Practical Application

A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.(no content)For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"},{"title":"Chetaev instability theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chetaev_instability_theorem"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Lyapunov functions and stability:

## Definition and Purpose

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Key Concept

Lyapunov's realization was that stability can be proven without requiring knowledge of the true physical energy, provided a Lyapunov function can be found to satisfy the above constraints. The intuition is similar to analyzing energy in physical systems: if the system loses energy over time and the energy is never restored then eventually the system must grind to a stop and reach some final resting state.

## Stability Types

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance...) remain close enough but asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

## Practical Application

A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.(no content)For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application in Nonlinear Control

Backstepping, along with feedback linearization, sliding mode control, and trajectory linearization control, normally takes advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.(no content)Systems in strict-feedback form can be stabilized by recursive application of backstepping.

## Historical Contribution

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Backstepping is a powerful technique for designing controllers for nonlinear systems that have a special structure, allowing complex high-order systems to be controlled by building up solutions from simpler subsystems.

Links: [{"title":"Stability criterion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_criterion"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Electronic stability control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_stability_control"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Nyquist stability criterion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyquist_stability_criterion"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of stability analysis in control systems:

## Definition

In control theory, a stability criterion establishes when a system is stable.

## Key Concepts and Methods

**Fundamental Approaches:**
- The stability of a general dynamical system with no input can be described with Lyapunov stability criteria.
- Tools for analysis include graphical systems like the root locus, Bode plots or the Nyquist plots.

**Lyapunov Stability:**
Lyapunov stability pioneered a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

**Nyquist Criterion:**
The most common use of Nyquist plots is for assessing the stability of a system with feedback.

## Linear vs. Nonlinear Systems

Linear systems can be solved by powerful frequency domain mathematical techniques of great generality, such as the Laplace transform, Fourier transform, Z transform, Bode plot, root locus, and Nyquist stability criterion.(no content)Techniques for nonlinear systems include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Important Related Concepts

Controllability and observability are main issues in the analysis of a system before deciding the best control strategy to be applied, or whether it is even possible to control or stabilize the system.

Web search results for query: "Feedback control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Sensitivity (control systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_(control_systems)"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Cybernetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about feedback control systems:

## Overview

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)Its name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired valueof the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Key Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

## Types of Feedback

If the signal feedback from output is in phase with the input signal, the feedback is called positive feedback. If the signal feedback is out of phase by 180° with respect to the input signal, the feedback is called negative feedback.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about feedback control systems:

## Overview

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)Its name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired valueof the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Key Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

## Types of Feedback

If the signal feedback from output is in phase with the input signal, the feedback is called positive feedback. If the signal feedback is out of phase by 180° with respect to the input signal, the feedback is called negative feedback.

I've completed the web search for "Adaptive control systems." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Distinction from Robust Control

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundation and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Historical Context

Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field.

## Real-World Applications

The search results show several practical applications:
- **Aviation**: A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control. This body of work has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.
- **Traffic Management**: Adaptive traffic control system (ATCS) is a traffic management strategy in which traffic signal timing changes, or adapts, based on actual traffic demand.
- **Vehicle Control**: Adaptive cruise control (ACC) is a type of advanced driver-assistance system for road vehicles that automatically adjusts the vehicle speed to maintain a safe distance from vehicles ahead.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Fuzzy Logic Systems:

## Overview

A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values of either 1 or 0.

## History

Fuzzy logic was proposed by Lotfi A. Zadeh of the University of California at Berkeley in a 1965 paper. The first industrial application, a cement kiln built in Denmark, came on line in 1976. Interest in fuzzy systems was sparked by Seiji Yasunobu and Soji Miyamoto of Hitachi, who in 1985 provided simulations demonstrating the feasibility of fuzzy control systems for the Sendai Subway, and their ideas were adopted when the Namboku Line opened in 1987.

## Key Characteristics

Since the fuzzy system output is a consensus of all of the inputs and all of the rules, fuzzy logic systems can be well behaved when input values are not available or are not trustworthy.

In a fuzzy rule, the premise and the consequent can be true to a degree, instead of entirely true or entirely false, achieved by representing the linguistic variables using fuzzy sets.

## Main Components and Process

The most well-known system is the Mamdani rule-based one, which uses the following rules: Fuzzify all input values into fuzzy membership functions, Execute all applicable rules in the rulebase to compute the fuzzy output functions, and De-fuzzify the fuzzy output functions to get "crisp" output values.

## Applications

Applications include handwriting recognition in Sony pocket computers, helicopter flight aids, subway system controls, improving automobile fuel efficiency, single-button washing machine controls, automatic power controls in vacuum cleaners, and early recognition of earthquakes.

Web search results for query: "State observer control theory"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"}]

## State Observer Control Theory

A state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

### Key Concepts

**Purpose and Necessity**

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

**Observability Requirement**

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)Observability is a measure of how well internal states of a system can be inferred from knowledge of its external outputs.

### Observer Types and Design

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

**High-Gain Observers**

When the observer gain is high, the linear Luenberger observer converges to the system states very quickly. However, high observer gain leads to a peaking phenomenon in which initial estimator error can be prohibitively large.(no content)Nonlinear high-gain observer methods are available that converge quickly without the peaking phenomenon.

### Integration with Control

A separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system. Thus the problem can be broken into two separate parts, which facilitates the design.

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"}]

## State Observer Control Theory

A state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

### Key Concepts

**Purpose and Necessity**

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

**Observability Requirement**

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)Observability is a measure of how well internal states of a system can be inferred from knowledge of its external outputs.

### Observer Types and Design

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

**High-Gain Observers**

When the observer gain is high, the linear Luenberger observer converges to the system states very quickly. However, high observer gain leads to a peaking phenomenon in which initial estimator error can be prohibitively large.(no content)Nonlinear high-gain observer methods are available that converge quickly without the peaking phenomenon.

### Integration with Control

A separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system. Thus the problem can be broken into two separate parts, which facilitates the design.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Nonlinear control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Chen Guanrong - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Guanrong"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of nonlinear control theory:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations. The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Mathematical Techniques

Techniques include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Practical Applications

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off". Therefore, the furnace is off until the temperature falls below the "turn on" setpoint of the thermostat, when it turns on. Due to the heat added by the furnace, the temperature increases until it reaches the "turn off" setpoint of the thermostat, which turns the furnace off, and the cycle repeats. This cycling of the temperature about the desired temperature is called a limit cycle, and is characteristic of nonlinear control systems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
